awd_titl_txt: Stable and Convergent Computational Algorithms for Current Density Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Coupling together two distinct physical fields in medical and geophysical imaging is capable of enhancing both the space and contrast resolution of imaging modalities. This project concerns one of such a modality - Current Density Imaging (CDI) that couples the magnetic and radio-frequency electromagnetic fields used in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with the electric field used in Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT). Such a coupling is resulted in images of the electrical conductivity with significantly higher quality and accuracy than those obtained by the routine medical imaging modalities.  The general aim of this project is to develop the computationally efficient and robust algorithms for CDI.
 
The proposed research is in the field of coupled physics (hybrid) inverse problems whose distinctive feature is utilizing the interior data available in new imaging modalities in order to reconstruct material parameters of an object to be investigated. Speaking about the possible applications of such inverse problems, it should be particularly emphasized medical diagnostics and marine controlled source electromagnetic sounding due to their importance for early detection of cancer, minimizing the rate of false diagnoses, more efficient treatment of diseases, etc., and for geophysical exploration of hydrocarbon deposits on a shelf. The innovation of this project is that it is concerned with the development of computational tools for CDI by utilizing an initial boundary value problem for the weighted mean curvature flow equation. In order to achieve the general aim, the principal investigator will: (1) analyze the level set formulation of motion by the weighted mean curvature associated with the Dirichlet problem for the weighted 1-Laplacian, which is considered as a mathematical model of CDI, (2) develop the stable and convergent computational algorithms, and (3) conduct the numerical convergence study in order to demonstrate in numerical experiments the effectiveness of computational algorithms and quality of reconstruction. The approach developed in this project is expected to advance understanding of the geometrical features of CDI. One undergraduate student will be involved in the project and trained in numerical methods for the inverse problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main finding resulted from activities stated above is that the weighted mean curvature flow formalism was justified. In particular, by analogy with the Sternberg-Ziemer theory of generalized motion by mean curvature with a Dirichlet condition, the existence and uniqueness results of the viscosity-like solution to the weighted mean curvature flow problem were established. Based on this, we developed some algorithms whose computational feasibility was demonstrated in a number of computer simulations of coupled physics conductivity imaging. Following Ladyzhenskaya, we first applied the Rothe method to the regularized problem in order to approximate it in time. This allowed for reducing the problem to a family of elliptic Dirichlet problems at any temporal layer. Then we constructed the second-order difference approximation of each elliptic problem. The resulting systems of linear algebraic equations were numerically solved by the PCG method, as well as by the regularized method of successive approximations developed previously by PI. These effective iterative procedures were used for computer simulations of coupled physics conductivity imaging. The large time behavior of the numerical solution to the regularized weighted mean curvature flow problem was observed and studied in series of numerical experiments. It was shown in finite precision that the numerical convergence to the solution of the weighted least gradient Dirichlet problem takes place when evolving in time the sought pair (voltage potential, conductivity) as the regularization parameters approaches zero. Moreover, the regularized solutions are robust with respect to perturbations of the internal data. The uniqueness and convergence results were established for the regularized weighted least gradient Robin problem, and the method of regularized successive iterations was justified and implemented numerically. Its computational effectiveness was demonstrated in the numerical experiments with the simulated data. The results of research were dissemenated at five national/international conferences/colloquia and published in six refereed mathematical journals with the natioal/international circulation. These results may provide a basis for development of computational algorithms for coupled physics conductivity imaging. They are likely to have impact on medical diagnostics and underwater electromagnetics, particularly on controlled source electromagnetic sounding.
